security_audit.summary: This is a documentation-only skill template with no executable code. It contains only markdown documentation for domain vocabulary management with no security risks.

content.value_statement: Inconsistent terminology creates confusion in codebases. This skill establishes a shared vocabulary and entity relationships for your project domain.
actual_capabilities: Documents domain entities and their definitions
Provides validation rules for domain logic
Integrates with ORM models and API schemas
limitations: Requires manual population of domain glossary
Template needs customization for specific projects
Relationship depth limited to 2 levels by default

use_cases.title: Define Domain Models
use_cases.description: Establish clear entity definitions and relationships for complex business domains before implementation.

use_cases.title: Enforce Naming Consistency
use_cases.description: Ensure all team members use consistent terminology across code, documentation, and discussions.

use_cases.title: Standardize API Schemas
use_cases.description: Maintain consistent field names and status values across REST APIs and database schemas.

prompt_templates.title: Basic Domain Setup
prompt_templates.prompt: Help me define the domain vocabulary for an e-commerce platform including Customer, Order, Product, and Payment entities with their relationships.

prompt_templates.title: Entity Relationships
prompt_templates.prompt: Document the relationships between User, Account, Subscription, and Billing entities in a SaaS application.

prompt_templates.title: Terminology Validation
prompt_templates.prompt: Check this codebase for inconsistent use of 'user' vs 'customer' terminology and suggest standardization.

prompt_templates.title: Domain Rules
prompt_templates.prompt: Create validation rules for order status transitions and payment processing in our domain model.

output_examples.input: Define domain vocabulary for a blog platform
output: - Author: User who creates blog posts
- Post: Published article with title, content, and metadata
- Tag: Category label for organizing posts
- Author 1-* Posts (one author writes many posts)
- Post 1-* Comments (each post has multiple comments)
- Post *-* Tags (posts can have multiple tags)

best_practices: Populate the glossary early in project development before coding begins
Review and update domain vocabulary when adding new features
Share the domain model with all team members and stakeholders
anti_patterns: Don't use different terms interchangeably (user vs customer vs client)
Avoid creating duplicate concepts with different names
Don't ignore relationship constraints when implementing features

faq.question: Is this compatible with existing projects?
faq.answer: Yes, you can retrofit domain vocabulary to existing projects by documenting current entities and standardizing terminology.

faq.question: What are the file size limits?
faq.answer: The skill documentation has no hard limits, but keep glossaries focused and maintainable for large domains.

faq.question: How does this integrate with my codebase?
faq.answer: It provides reference documentation that aligns with your models in src/models/, BAML types, and API schemas.

faq.question: Is my project data safe?
faq.answer: Yes, this is documentation-only with no code execution or data access - it only contains domain definitions.

faq.question: What if my domain changes?
faq.answer: Update the SKILL.md file to reflect new entities, relationships, or terminology as your project evolves.

faq.question: How is this different from UML diagrams?
faq.answer: It focuses on vocabulary consistency rather than visual modeling, with practical rules for code implementation.
